deliberation: Checked the chronological and geographical data (literal) and the vision formula. The sole non-literal phrasing is "the heavens were opened," which personifies heaven to express the onset of revelation.

instances.english_text: the heavens opened
vehicle: heavens opening like a door or curtain
ground: sudden transition from hidden to visible/accessibility
posture: vision-reporting language framing an inner experience as an external opening
instances.explanation: Heaven is personified as something that can be "opened" to convey the sudden accessibility of divine realities to the prophet.

deliberation: The verse is a bare chronological note giving a date in Jehoiachin’s exile, with no non-literal expressions.

Examined standard prophetic formulas. Found (1) "word of YHWH came" as a metonymy for divine communication, and (2) "hand of YHWH was upon him" as an anthropomorphic metaphor/personification for God’s powerful influence.

instances.english_text: the word of the LORD came to Ezekiel
target: God’s act of communicating with Ezekiel
ground: a message is something spoken or said, so "word" can stand for the whole act of communicating
posture: fixed prophetic formula stressing that the source is YHWH, not the prophet
instances.explanation: The concrete "word" stands metonymically for the whole revelatory act in which God communicates His will to Ezekiel.

instances.english_text: and the hand of the LORD came upon him there
ground: a hand exerts control, power, and guidance, so God’s influence is pictured as a hand resting on someone
posture: anthropomorphic and experiential language to make divine action intelligible
instances.explanation: God is described as having a "hand" that comes upon Ezekiel, a metaphorical personification conveying overpowering divine control and guidance.

deliberation: Most elements (storm-wind, cloud, fire) function as visionary but are linguistically literal. The explicit comparative marker כ introduces a simile likening the inner radiance to the appearance of ḥashmal (amber/electrum).

instances.english_text: and in the center of it, in the center of the fire, a gleam as of amber
target: the central radiance within the storm-cloud fire
manifested divine glory in the vision
posture: epistemic hedging ("like the appearance") indicating approximation to something ineffable
instances.explanation: Ezekiel uses a simile, comparing the difficult-to-describe inner radiance to the recognizable gleam of ḥashmal.

deliberation: The term דְּמוּת (likeness/figure) signals that the description is analogical rather than strictly literal. The creatures are described by likeness to a human form, functioning as an anthropomorphic metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: דְּמוּת אַרְבַּע חַיּוֹת ... דְּמוּת אָדָם לָהֵנָּה
instances.english_text: the figures of four creatures... They had the figures of human beings
ground: upright, humanoid bodily configuration that makes them intelligible to the seer
posture: cautious "likeness" language marking partial but not total identity with human form
instances.explanation: The otherwise unknown creatures are characterized by analogy to human form using "likeness" language, functioning as an anthropomorphic metaphor.

deliberation: This verse is an anomalous but straightforward anatomical description of the creatures in the vision (four faces and four wings), with no explicit comparative markers or conventional figurative idioms.
The creatures’ single straight leg is literal within the vision. Two expressions with כ introduce explicit similes: feet like a calf’s hoof and their sparkle like burnished bronze.

instances.english_text: and the feet of each were like a single calf’s hoof
target: the feet of the living creatures
ground: similar split, rounded shape and perhaps firmness
posture: use of familiar animal anatomy to describe an unfamiliar heavenly form
instances.explanation: The creatures’ feet are compared to a calf’s hoof to convey their shape by a familiar animal image.

instances.english_text: and their sparkle was like the luster of burnished bronze
target: the visual surface of the creatures’ legs/feet
posture: analogy to a known polished metal to capture extraordinary brilliance
instances.explanation: Their shine is likened to polished bronze, a simile conveying intense metallic brilliance.

deliberation: The description of human hands under wings and placement of faces and wings is fantastic but presented straightforwardly without comparative particles or figurative idioms.
Movement and non-turning are literal within the vision. The phrase "woman to her sister" is a conventional idiom for close pairing or adjacency, functioning figuratively.

instances.english_text: each one’s wings touched those of the other (lit. "a woman to her sister were their wings")
target: mutual joining of the creatures’ wings
ground: intimate nearness and pairing, side by side
posture: use of a conventional Semitic idiom for items joined in pairs
instances.explanation: The idiom "a woman to her sister" is used figuratively to describe how closely their wings adjoin one another.

deliberation: Although the composite faces (human, lion, ox, eagle) are symbolically loaded, the language itself is simple predication without explicit comparative or idiomatic markers.
The verse elaborates wing configuration and body covering literally within the logic of the vision; it uses no similes, metaphors, or idioms.
Movement "wherever the spirit would go" may reflect theology of divine impulse, but it is expressed straightforwardly without explicit figurative devices as defined here.
This verse explicitly uses כ to compare the creatures’ appearance and the fiery phenomena to burning coals and to torches. Both are similes intended to capture visual quality and motion.

instances.english_text: the appearance of the creatures was like burning coals of fire
target: the appearance of the living creatures (or their associated fiery aspect)
ground: glowing, intense heat and light, ember-like quality
posture: simile marking approximation of unfamiliar beings to familiar fiery coals
instances.explanation: The creatures’ appearance is likened to burning coals, emphasizing their glowing, ember-like intensity.

instances.english_text: like the appearance of torches
target: the moving fire among the creatures
posture: analogy to a familiar portable flame to express motion and form
instances.explanation: The fire moving among the creatures is likened to torches, conveying flickering, mobile flames.

deliberation: The movement "ran and returned" is literal within the sequence; the explicit כ introduces a single simile comparing their motion to lightning.

instances.english_text: and the creatures sped to and fro, like the appearance of lightning
target: the speed and manner of the creatures’ movement
ground: extreme rapidity and sudden, darting motion
posture: simile to convey otherwise inexpressible speed
instances.explanation: Their dashing motion is compared to a lightning flash to highlight its incredible speed and suddenness.

deliberation: This is a narrative notice of the prophet seeing a wheel beside each creature; language is descriptive, not figurative.
The structure "a wheel within a wheel" is unusual but literal in the vision. The phrase כְעֵין תַּרְשִׁישׁ is a clear simile likening the wheels’ appearance to beryl.

instances.english_text: as for the appearance and structure of the wheels, they gleamed like beryl
target: visual quality of the chariot wheels
posture: use of a known precious stone to describe extraordinary appearance
instances.explanation: The wheels are compared to beryl to describe their gem-like, gleaming appearance.

deliberation: Directional movement and non-turning of wheels are described literally with no comparative or idiomatic expressions.
Though eyes covering the rims are symbolically suggestive, within the vision they are presented as literal features; the verse contains no similes, metaphors, or idioms by form.
This synchronizes movement of creatures and wheels, using straightforward narrative description without figurative markers.
The "spirit" in the wheels can be theologically rich, but linguistically it is a direct assertion, not framed as metaphor, simile, or idiom in this verse.
Reiterates the coordination of creatures and wheels, still in plain descriptive prose with no figurative forms detectable.
The expanse above the creatures’ heads is likened explicitly to awesome crystal/ice by כְעֵין, constituting a simile; the rest is literal spatial description.

instances.english_text: an expanse, with an awe-inspiring gleam as of crystal
target: the firmament-like expanse over the creatures’ heads
posture: simile highlighting both look and terror of the expanse
instances.explanation: The expanse is compared to awe-inspiring crystal/ice to express its terrifying, glittering clarity.

deliberation: Details about wings extended toward one another and covering bodies function as literal features of the visionary beings; no explicit figurative devices occur.
This verse is rich in auditory similes, comparing the sound of the wings to (1) many waters, (2) the sound of Shaddai, and (3) the tumult of an army. All are coded by כ.

instances.english_text: the sound of their wings was like the sound of mighty waters
target: sound of the creatures’ wings in motion
posture: simile that anchors a novel sound in a familiar natural roar
instances.explanation: The wings’ sound is likened to roaring waters to convey its overwhelming, powerful volume.

instances.english_text: like the sound of Shaddai
ground: sense of divine presence and power
posture: simile that explicitly aligns the sound with God’s own voice
instances.explanation: The wings’ sound is compared to the voice of Shaddai, stressing its divine, majestic character.

instances.english_text: a tumult like the din of an army
target: the composite roaring tumult of the wings
vehicle: noise of troops and military activity
posture: simile using military soundscape to portray the ordered yet tumultuous noise
instances.explanation: The noise is likened to an army’s din to convey the loud, many-sourced, and imposing character of the sound.

deliberation: A "voice" from above the expanse is mentioned without any comparative or idiomatic embellishment; language is direct and literal within the vision.

Two figurative elements appear: (1) the throne’s appearance is compared to sapphire (simile), and (2) the one upon it is described as "likeness as appearance of a man," an anthropomorphic metaphor for the divine presence.

instances.english_text: the semblance of a throne, in appearance like sapphire
target: the appearance of the heavenly throne
posture: simile to render a transcendent throne intelligible via a known gemstone
instances.explanation: The throne’s look is compared to sapphire to emphasize its brilliant, precious, blue radiance.

instances.hebrew_text: וְעַל דְּמוּת הַכִּסֵּא דְּמוּת כְּמַרְאֵה אָדָם עָלָיו מִלְמָעְלָה
instances.english_text: and upon this semblance of a throne, there was the semblance of a human form seated above
vehicle: human figure seated on a throne
ground: recognizable bodily form, capacity for relationship and rule
posture: intentionally cautious anthropomorphic metaphor ("likeness as appearance") signaling both similarity and otherness
instances.explanation: The transcendent God is portrayed in the likeness of a human figure on a throne, an anthropomorphic metaphor expressing kingship and relationality.

deliberation: This verse piles up כ-phrases: the upper part is like the appearance of ḥashmal and like the appearance of fire within a frame, and the lower part is like the appearance of fire. These are three distinct but related similes.

instances.english_text: a gleam as of amber
target: the upper-body appearance of the enthroned figure
posture: simile groping for language for indescribable brightness
instances.explanation: The upper part of the figure looks like ḥashmal, a simile conveying intense metallic gleam.

instances.english_text: like the appearance of fire encased in a frame all around
target: the structured radiance around the upper torso
vehicle: fire within a frame or enclosure
fiery phenomenon shaped by an object
ground: intense fire constrained within definite boundaries
posture: simile elaborating the form of the radiance, not just its brightness
instances.explanation: The radiance is compared to fire enclosed in a frame, highlighting both its fiery nature and its defined shape.

instances.english_text: and from what appeared as the loins down, I saw what looked like fire
target: the lower-body appearance of the enthroned figure
ground: fiery brightness, possibly connoting energy and judgment
posture: simile simplifying the description of the lower half purely to "fire"
instances.explanation: The lower part of the figure is likened to fire, emphasizing unmediated fiery radiance.

deliberation: Detected two related figurative moves: (1) a simile comparing the surrounding radiance to a rainbow in a rain-cloud, and (2) the statement that this was the "appearance of the likeness of the glory of YHWH," which metaphorically identifies the visible vision with God’s intangible glory.

instances.hebrew_text: כְּמַרְאֵה הַקֶּשֶׁת אֲשֶׁר יִהְיֶה בֶעָנָן בְּיוֹם הַגֶּשֶׁם כֵּן מַרְאֵה הַנֹּגַהּ סָבִיב
instances.english_text: like the appearance of the bow that is in the cloud on a day of rain, such was the appearance of the surrounding radiance
target: the surrounding radiance around the enthroned figure
vehicle: rainbow in the cloud on a rainy day
ground: arched, multicolored, luminous beauty after a storm, often associated with covenant
colorful brightness and hope after judgment
posture: simile that both describes appearance and evokes covenantal associations of the rainbow
instances.explanation: The radiance is likened to a rainbow, conveying its multicolored brilliance and likely evoking covenantal overtones.

instances.english_text: that was the appearance of the semblance of the Presence (glory) of the LORD
target: the total visionary phenomenon Ezekiel has just described
ground: the vision conveys overwhelming majesty, holiness, and presence characteristic of God’s "glory"
posture: highly cautious metaphor using "appearance" and "likeness" to avoid direct identification of God with the image
instances.explanation: Ezekiel identifies the vision as the "appearance of the likeness of the glory of YHWH," a guarded metaphor equating the visible display with God’s otherwise invisible majesty.
